column1: A small circle appears in [[Forlindon]] on Tolkien's early draft map for ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''.<ref>{{HM
column2: TI}}, p. 302</ref> Christopher Tolkien cannot explain this feature<ref>{{HM
column3: TI}}, p. 301</ref> and notes that in his own 1943 redrawn map, the circular area is no longer present.<ref>{{HM
column4: TI}}, p. 322</ref> If one does a correct collage of Beleriand and Eriador maps, however, the small circular map seems to coincide with Amon Ereb.<ref>See notably the maps independently reconstructed by [[Charles Noad]], "A Note on the Geography of the First Age" in ''[[Amon_Hen_(journal)
column8: 27]], September 1990, p. 40; [[Ronald Kyrmse]], "The Geographical Relation between Beleriand and Eriador" in ''[[Mallorn_(journal)
column10: 26]], September 1989, pp. 25–27; [[Didier Willis]], "Du Beleriand aux confins de Rhûn" (French) in ''[[Tolkien, le façonnement d'un monde]]'' (2014), vol. 2, pp. 197-212.</ref> This might suggest that Amon Ereb was once thought to have survived the submersion of Beleriand, although there is no textual evidence for it.

column1: In MERP, Amon Ereb does indeed survive the destruction of [[Beleriand]].
